div.head: Introduction
div.p: For a decade, the consensus problem for multi-agent systems (MASs) has been studied extensively by various scientific communities due to its broad applications in robots, formation control of unmanned air vehicles, sensor networks and so on [1]. Consensus requires all agents to achieve a desired common goal using only neighboring information [2]. Until now, the existing works about consensus are mainly focus on the single-integrator dynamics or double-integrator kinematics or fractional-order kinematics [3][4][5][6][7][8][9]. Recently, some investigators have extended those simple models to general linear dynamic systems. For example, Ref. [2] has studied the leader-following consensus problem for a group of agents with identical general linear systems and Ref. [10] has studied the eventbased consensus problem for general linear multi-agent systems. Leader-following approach is commonly adopted by researchers to help agents arrive at the desired destination [11]. For a multi-agent system, each agent can be controlled by an embedded micro-processor who is used to receive information from neighboring agents. Information among agents is transmitted through communication networks. In practice, communication networks, especially wireless networks, have bandwidth limitations that may cause delays or disorders in message delivery. Such limitations may seriously degrade the system's stability performance. To solve this communication issue, control strategy has been drawn an increasing attention in more recent years for its benefits in saving the communication resources and reducing the communication burden [12]. This is done by having agents broadcast their state information signals only in the case of occurrence of local events that are triggered depending on some predesigned rulings. The event-triggered consensus control problem for MASs was investigated earlier by the research group guided by D. V. Dimarogonas [12]. From then on, many valuable research results have been appeared event-triggered control for MASs with single-integrator dynamics or double-integrator kinematics [10,[13][14][15][16][17]. However, this novel control strategy has not been studied extensively for MASs with general linear models [2].

Although much consideration has been paid on the event-triggered consensus control MASs, the existing results do not take into account the situation that the control input is often subject to saturation owing to some physical limitations [18][19][20][21][22]. For example, the ability of each robot to adjust its orientation for achieving the desired formation is limited. The protocol design for achieving consensus for MASs with input saturation constraints is a challenging problem and by now only few relative results can be available for the consensus of MASs but based on the traditional time-triggered control. For example, Ref. [23] has investigated the global leader-following consensus of continuoustime linear MASs subject to actuator saturation by using the relative potential functions. Ref. [20] has studied the global leader-less consensus of discrete-time linear MASs with input saturation constraints by using the Lyapunov functional method. Ref. [18] has studied the semi-global leader-following consensus of continuous-time linear MASs with input saturation via low gain feedback. Furthermore, Ref. [22] has addressed the semi-global consensus of nonlinear second-order leader-following MASs with measurement output feedback. However, according to the authors' knowledge, input saturation has not been taken into account in the open literature for the consensus control problem of MASs by using the novel event-triggered communication scheme. In contrast, just during the last two years, there appeared few results in the literature for networked control systems subject to input saturation by using the event-triggered control, see for example [24][25][26].

Motivated by the above mentions and also taking the following significant reason into account: in the practical systems, as stated in [27][28][29], agents may have intrinsic nonlinear dynamics, in this paper we will address the consensus problem for nonlinear MASs in directed networks with general models and input saturation based on the event-triggered communication scheme. To study the consensus problem with saturation under event-triggered scheme is not only theoretically challenging but also practically imperative. The main contributions of this paper can be sated as follows:

(1) Two kinds of distributed event-triggered control scheme are introduced, one is continuous-time based eventtriggered scheme and the other is sampled-data based event-triggered scheme. The parameters of the event-triggering functions used in our paper are no longer constant parameters as used in [14,30] but adaptively adjusted with time according to some event-error-dependent adaptive laws. For the continuous-time based event-triggered scheme, the 2 Downloaded by [Stockholm University Library] at 22:01 04 September 2015 Notation: I N denotes the identity matrix with dimension N. S N {1, 2, . . . , N}. We write P > 0 for a positive definite matrix. In symmetric block matrices, we use ( * ) as an ellipsis for terms that can be induced by symmetry. Z + denotes the set of positive integers. We use the notation diag{ m 1 , m 2 , . . . , m N } to denote the diagonal matrix

A c c e p t e d M a n u s c r i p t adaptive laws satisfy some differential equations, while for the sampled-data based event-triggered scheme, the adaptive laws satisfy some difference equations. So the difficulties in choosing suitable initial parameters can be avoided.

(2) By using the sector nonlinearity model approach to deal with the input saturation and by using the Lyapunov functional analysis method, it will be shown that all agents in the group with a virtual leader can reach the leaderfollowing consensus when only a subgroup of the agents can access to the leader's state information. Furthermore, the controller gain and the event-triggering parameter can be co-designed in terms of LMI techniques.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents some concepts about graph theory and the consensus problem to be solved in this paper. The continuous-time based event-triggered control scheme is proposed in Section 3 and the sampled-data based event-triggered control scheme is proposed in Section 4. Simulation results are presented to illustrate the effectiveness of the theoretical results in Section 5. Section 6 offers some conclusions.

div.head: Graph Theory
div.p: A directed graph G(A) = (V, E, A) of order N consists a set of vertices V = {v 1 , . . . , v n } and a set of directed edges E = {e i j = (v i , v j )} ⊂ V × V and a weighted adjacency matrix A = [a i j ] having non-negative entries. An edge denoted as e i j = (v i , v j ) means that the jth agent can receive the ith agent's information, but not necessarily vice versa.
If e i j ∈ E, then we say the ith agent is a neighbor of the jth agent. The set of neighbors of node v i is denoted by
div.formula: N i := {v j |e ji = (v j , v i ) ∈ E}. A directed path from vertex v i to v j is a sequence of edges (v i , v i1 ), (v i 1 , v i 2 ), . . .,(v i l , v j )
div.p: with distinct vertices v i k , k = 1, 2, . . . , l. A directed graph contains a directed spanning tree if there exists a vertex called root such that there exists a directed path from this root to every other vertex. The adjacency matrix for the N×N , where a i j > 0 if (v j , v i ) ∈ E and a i j = 0, otherwise. Here we assume that a ii = 0 for ∀i ∈ V. The Laplacian matrix L = [l i j ] for G is defined as l ii = -N j=1, j i l i j , l i j = -a i j , i j [14].
div.formula: communication graph of N agents is A = [a i j ] ∈ R

div.head: System Model Statement
div.p: The multi-agent system considered in this paper consists of N following agents indexed by 1, 2, . . . N and a virtual leader indexed by 0. Each agent is described by
div.formula: ẋi (t) = Ax i (t) + f (x i (t), t) + Bσ(u i (t))(1)
div.p: A c c e p t e d M a n u s c r i p t
where x i (t) ∈ R n and u i (t) ∈ R p denote the state and control input of the ith agent, f (x i (t), t) ∈ R n is its nonlinear dynamics, σ : R p → R p is a saturation function defined as σ(u
div.formula: i ) = [ sat(u i1 ) sat(u i2 ) • • • sat(u ip ) ] T , sat(u i j ) =
div.p: sgn(u i j ) min u i j , u 0 for some constant u 0 > 0. A and B are constant matrices with suitable dimensions. x 0 is called the leader, which does not have to be an actual leader but is specified by (2) with f (x 0 (t), t) be its intrinsic nonlinear dynamics. The initial conditions are x i0 = x i (0). i ∈ S N .
Assumption 1. [31] The nonlinear function f : R n → R n satisfies the Lipschitz condition, i.e.,
for any x, y ∈ R n .
Assumption 2. The communication network has a directed spanning tree.

Remark 1. Assumption 2 implies that every agent, for example, agent i, can have at least one neighboring agent x j i and this conclusion is important for the following event-triggered communication scheme design.
The definition of the local consensus is given as follows.
Definition 1. Let the ellipsoid ξ(P, η)
div.formula: x i (t), i ∈ S N ∪ {0}| N i=1 (x i (t) -x 0 (t)) T P(x i (t) -x 0 (t)) ≤ η ,
div.p: where η > 0 is a scalar and P is a positive definite matrix. The nonlinear MASs ( 1) and (2) with control protocol u i is said to reach local leader-following consensus, if for any initial state values {x i (0), i ∈ S N ∪ {0}} ∈ ξ(P, η), the states of agents satisfy lim
div.formula: t→∞ x i (t) -x 0 (t) = 0, i ∈ S N .

div.head: Design of the event-triggered mechanism
div.p: In order to save the communication energy of the multi-agent network, in the following, the distributed eventtriggered scheme will be introduced. Each agent has different event-triggered condition compared with others, though with a similar structure. Define the trigger function as h i (•, •) : R n × R n → R, for agent i, which depends on the local information of agent i only. Let x i (t) denote the value of x i (t) at the event-triggered time of agent i, denote the time by
div.formula: t i m (m = 0, 1, 2, ..., i ∈ S N ). Then x i (t) = x i (t i m ), t ∈ [t i m , t i m+1 ).(4)
div.p: In this paper, an event for agent i is triggered as soon as the following relationship is violated

The trigger functions h i (•, •) are designed as where y i (t) = x i (t) -x 0 (t) (and y i (t) = x i (t) -x 0 (t)) if agent i can access to the leader's state information x 0 (t), otherwise, y i (t) = x i (t) -x j i (t) (and y i (t) = x i (t) -x j i (t)) where j i can be any neighboring agent of agent i and e i (t) = y i (t) -y i (t), i ∈ S N . Assume that the first l agents can the leader's information x 0 (t), then we have
div.formula: h i (e i (t), y i (t)) = e T i (t)Ω i e i (t) -μ i (t)y T i (t)Ω i y i (t),(6) μi
(t) = -d i μ 2 i (t)e T i (t)Ω i e i (t)(7)
e i (t) = y i (t) -y i (t) = x i (t) -x 0 (t) -x i (t) + x 0 (t) = x i (t) -x i (t), i ∈ S l . (8
e i (t) = y i (t) -y i (t) = x i (t) -x j i (t) -x i (t) -x j i (t) = x i (t) -x i (t), i = l + 1, l + 2, . . . , N. (9

Based on the event-triggered scheme (5-7) and under the assumption that the leader is not triggered in this paper, the event-triggered control scheme for systems (1) and ( 2) is designed as follows:

div.head: Stability analysis
div.p: For the analysis use in the following, we first give several lemmas.

and the feedback gain K in (10) will be carried out in terms of LMI techniques.

div.p: and let G j = G j (I N ⊗ P), inequality (22) can be rewritten to get (19). Altogether, we can say that the asymptotic stability of system ( 17) is ensured for any δ(t) ∈ ξ(P, η) because V(t) < 0 holds for all t ≥ 0. This completes the proof.

div.head: Sampled-data based event-triggered control
div.p: By now, most of the existing event-triggering conditions need to be continuously monitored. This may lead to a waste utilization of communication and computation resources. In order to mitigate this limitation, in this section, we will apply the sampled-data based event-triggering scheme, which allows the event-triggering to be intermittently examined at constant sampling instants.

div.head: Design of the event-triggered mechanism
div.p: In this section, denote the kth transmitted instant of the sampled-data of agent i by t i k h, the next broadcasting instant t i k+1 h of it is accordingly determined by the following event-triggering function
div.formula: g i (•, •) = α T i (t i k h + l i h) T Ω i α i (t i k h + l i h) -μ i (t i k h + l i h)y T i (t i k h + l i h)Ω i y i (t i k h + l i h), (24
μ i (t i k h + l i h) -μ i (t i k h + l i h -h) = -d i hμ i (t i k h + l i h)μ i (t i k h + l i h -h)α i (t i k h + l i h) T Ω i α i (t i k h + l i h) (25
div.p: where
div.formula: α i (t i k h + l i h) = x i (t i k h + l i h) -x i (t i k h), y i (t i k h + l i h) = x i (t i k h + l i h) -x 0 (t i k h + l i h) if agent i can access to the leader's information, otherwise, y i (t i k h + l i h) = x i (t i k h + l i h) - ,

div.head: A c c e p t e d M a n u s c r i p t
div.p: Based on above event-triggered scheme (24)(25), the sampled-data based event-triggered consensus control protocol designed as follows:
div.formula: u i (t) = -K          j∈N i a i j x i (t i k h) -x j (t j k j h) + b i (x i (t i k h) -x 0 (mh))          (26) t ∈ [t i k h, t i k+1 h) ∩ [mh, (m + 1)h).

div.head: Modeling of the event-triggered MASs
div.p: Let e i (mh)
div.formula: = x i (t i k h) -x i (mh), we can obtain that [t i k h, t i k+1 h) = ∪ t i k+1 -1 m=t i k [mh, (m + 1)h
div.p: ), e j (mh) = x j (t j k j h) -x j (mh). So, for t ∈ [mh, (m + 1)h), the sampled-data based event-triggered consensus control protocol (26) can be rewritten as
div.formula: u i (t) = -K          j∈N i a i j x i (mh) + e i (mh) -x j (mh) -e j (mh) + b i (x i (mh) + e i (mh) -x 0 (mh))          . (27
div.p: Define an artificial delay function τ(t) = tmh, t ∈ [mh, (m + 1)h), and define the augmented vectors as in (13)(14)(15)(16), then the augmented systems of systems ( 1) and ( 2) with control ( 27) can be given as
div.formula: δ(t) = (I N ⊗ A) δ(t) + F(x(t), t) -F(x 0 (t), t) + (I N ⊗ B) σ -L ⊗ K δ(mh) -L ⊗ K e(mh) = (I N ⊗ A) δ(t) + F(x(t), t) -F(x 0 (t), t) + (I N ⊗ B) σ -L ⊗ K δ(t -τ(t)) -L ⊗ K e(t -τ(t)) .(28)
div.p: Remark 5. Compared with the closed-loop system (17) for the continuous-time based event-triggered control, the closed-loop system (28) obtained here is more complex since it becomes a nonlinear system with time delay, so the analysis process for system (28) will be not routine.
Remark 6. Clearly, τ(t) is piecewise-linear with the derivative τ(t) = 1 at t mh and discontinuous at t = mh . It is easily known that 0 ≤ τ(t) < h.

div.head: Lemma 5. For given initial values μ
div.formula: i (0) ∈ (0, 1], i ∈ S N , then e T i (mh)Ω i e i (mh) ≤ μ i (mh)y T i (mh)Ω i y i (mh) and furthermore 0 < μ i (mh) ≤ μ i (0) ≤ 1, i ∈ S N , m ∈ {1, 2, . . .} Proof 2.
div.p: From the event-triggering function (24), the following inequality holds for any m ∈ {1, 2, . . .}
div.formula: e T i (mh)Ω i e i (mh) ≤ μ i (mh)y T i (mh)Ω i y i (mh)
div.p: where y i (mh) = x i (mh)-x 0 (mh) if agent i can access to the leader's information, otherwise, y i (mh) = x i (mh)-x j (t j k j h). In the following, we will proof this lemma by using the mathematical induction method. For k = 1, from (25) we can obtain that
div.formula: μ i (h) -μ i (0) = -d i hμ i (h)μ i (0)α T i (0)Ω i α i (
μ i (h) = μ i (0) 1 + d i hμ i (0)α T i (0)Ω i α i (0)

It is obvious that 0 < μ i (h) ≤ μ i (0) ≤ 1 since μ i (0) ∈ (0, 1] and d i hμ i (0)α T i (h)Ω i α i (h) ≥ 0. For ∀k ∈ {2, 3, . . .}, it is assumed that 0 < μ i (kh) ≤ μ i (0) ≤ 1, now we just need to that 0 < μ i ((k + 1)h) ≤ μ i (0) ≤ 1.
div.p: Also, due to the relationship (25), we can derive that
div.formula: μ i ((k + 1)h) = μ i (kh) 1 + d i hμ i (kh)α T i (kh)Ω i α i (kh)
div.p: The above equality implies that 0
div.formula: < μ i ((k + 1)h) ≤ μ i (kh) ≤ 1 since μ i (kh) ≤ μ i (0) ∈ (0, 1] and d i hμ i (0)α T i (h)Ω i α i (h) ≥ 0.
div.p: This completes the proof.

div.head: Remark 7. According to Lemma 2 and 5, similar to

div.p: where
div.formula: μ 0 = diag{ μ 1 (0), μ 2 (0), • • • , μ N (0) } ⊗ I n and Δ 0 = M T N T μ 0 Ω M N .
div.p: In the following, we will derive a sufficient condition on the stability of ( 28) under the event-triggered control strategy (24)(25)(26). The design for the event-triggering Ω i in (24)(25) and the feedback gain K in (26) will also be carried out in terms of LMI techniques.

Theorem 2. Under the local event-triggered control laws (26) with the event-triggering (24)(25), for given scalars L > 0, ρ 1 , ρ 2 > 0, u 0 > 0, the group of the follower agents (1) achieve local leader-following consensus , if there exist positive definite matrices P > 0, R > 0, Q 1 > 0, Q 2 > 0, Ω i > 0, i ∈ S N , positive definite diagonal matrix Γ > 0, matrices Y and G with suitable dimensions and parameter η > 0 such that the following LMIs are satisfied:
div.formula: Υ 11 = I N ⊗ (A P + PA T ) + Q 2 -R, Υ 21 = -L T ⊗ Y T B T + R, Υ 51 = -Γ(I N ⊗ B T ) -G, Υ 88 = ρ 2 1 R -2ρ 1 P, Υ 92 = M(I N ⊗ P), Υ 94 = N(I N ⊗ P), Υ 99 = μ -1 0 (ρ 2 2 Ω -2ρ 2 P)
div.p: and
div.formula: Ω = diag{ Ω 1 , Ω 2 , • • • , Ω N }.
div.p: Furthermore, the explicit of the feedback gain K and the matrices Ω i are given as
div.formula: K = Y P -1 , Ω i = P -1 Ω i P -1 , i ∈ S N . Proof 3. By setting v = -L ⊗ K δ(t -τ(t)) -L ⊗ K e(t -τ(t)) Θ(t -τ(t)) and w = Θ(t -τ(t)) + Gδ(t)

div.p: Choose the Lyapunov function for system (28) as
div.formula: V(t, δ(t), δ(t)) = δ T (t) (I N ⊗ P) δ(t) + t-τ(t) t-h δ T (s)Q 1 δ T (s)ds + t t-τ(t) δ T (s)Q 2 δ T (s)ds +h 0 -h t t+θ δT (s)R δ(s)dsdθ(35)
div.p: Taking the derivative of ( 35) along the trajectory (28) with respect to t ∈ [mh, (m + 1)h), using (29) and the fact that τ(t) = 1 at t kh, we have

div.head: By using the Jensen inequality, we can obtain that
div.formula: -h t t-h δT (s)R δ(s)ds = -h t-τ(t) t-h δT (s)R δ(s)ds -h t t-τ(t) δT (s)R δ(s)ds ≤ -[δ(t -τ(t)) -δ(t -h)] T R[δ(t -τ(t)) -δ(t -h)] -[δ(t) -δ(t -τ(t))] T R[δ(t) -δ(t -τ(t))].(36)
div.p: Taking into account (28) and ( 36), we have
div.formula: V(t, δ(t), δ(t)) ≤ ζ T (t)(Λ + Π T RΠ + T μ 0 Ω )ζ(t) where ζ T (t) = δ T (t) δ T (t -τ(t)) δ T (t -h) e T (t -τ(t)) φ T (Θ(t -τ(t))) F T (x(t), t) -F T (x 0 (t), t) and Λ =                             I N ⊗ (PA + A T P) + Q 2 + L 2 I N×n -R * * * * * -L T ⊗ K T B T P + R -2R * * * * 0 R -Q 1 -R * * * -L T ⊗ K T B T P 0 0 -Ω * * -I N ⊗ B T P -ΓG Γ(L ⊗ K) 0 Γ(L ⊗ K) -2Γ * I N ⊗ P 0 0 0 0 -I N×n                             , Π = hI N ⊗ A -hL ⊗ BK 0 -hL ⊗ BK -hI N ⊗ B hI N×n . = 0 M 0 N 0 0 .
div.p: It can be ensured that V(t) < 0 as long as
div.formula: Λ + Π T RΠ + T μ 0 Ω < 0. (37
div.p: By using Schur complement, the above inequality (37
Pre and post-multiplying (38) with diag{ I N ⊗ P -1 , I N ⊗ P -1 , I N ⊗ P -1 , I N ⊗ P -1 , Γ -1 , I N×n , I N×n , I N×n } and defining the following new matrix variables as
div.formula: P = P -1 , G = G(I N ⊗ P), Y = K P, Ω = PΩ P, Γ = Γ -1 , R = PR P, Q 1 = PQ 1 P, Q 2 = PQ 2 P
div.p: and taking into account the following relationship obtained by Lemma 3

2 Ω -2ρ 2 P for any positive scalars ρ 1 and ρ 2 , inequality (38) can be guaranteed if LMI (30) is satisfied. Furthermore, pre and post-multiplying (34) with diag{ I N ⊗ P -1 , 1 } and let G j = G j (I N ⊗ P), inequality (34) can be rewritten to (31). Altogether, we can say that the asymptotic stability of system (28) is ensured for any δ(t) ∈ ξ(P, η) because V(t) < 0 holds for all t ≥ 0. This completes the proof.

Remark 8. Work [16] has investigated the sampled-data based event-triggered leader-less consensus for general linear multi-agent systems without input saturation constraint. However, the MASs we investigated here nonlinear dynamics and to input saturation. Furthermore, the event-triggered parameters μ i are adaptively adjusted here according to (25) while in work [16] the event-triggered parameters σ i are some constants given in advance.
A c c e p t e d M a n u s c r i p t

div.head: Numerical example
div.p: In this section, the simulation is performed with four following agents and a leader to illustrate the theoretical results. Each agent is assumed to be a vertical taking-off and landing (VTOL) aircraft. The dynamics of four VTOL aircraft and the leader for a typical loading and flight condition at the air speed of 135 kt [35] are described by the systems (1) and (2), where the constant matrices A and B are given as follows

The state variables are: x i1 -horizontal velocity; x i2 -vertical velocity; x i3 -pitch rate; x i4 -pitch angle. The control inputs are given by u i1 -collective and u i2 -longitudinal cyclic.The nonlinear functions are assumed to be external
div.formula: disturbances with f (x i (t), t) = 0 0 0 -0.1 sin(x i3 ) , i ∈ S 4 ∪ {0}.
div.p: The communication topology is shown in Fig. 1. We can easily obtain the corresponding adjacent matrix A and the Laplace matrix L as follows:
Since the first two agents can access to the leader's information, we set L 0 = diag 1, 1, 0, 0 .
Case 1. The continuous-time based event-triggered control.

For this case, u i (t) is defined in (10), the triggering conditions in (5) with triggering functions in (6)(7) are applied to the event-triggered control strategy. By solving the corresponding LMIs (18)(19) in Theorem 1 with L = 0.1, γ = 200, ρ = 0.02, u 0 = 1 and μ i (0) = 0.3, d i = 1, i ∈ S 4 , the triggering parameter matrix Ω i and the feedback gain matrix K are obtained as Furthermore, to help the readers' understanding, we also compute out the average eventtriggered time intervals for the two cases in Table 2.

A c c e p t e d M a n u s c r i p t and η = 8.6142 × 10 -4 . The initial states are randomly chosen in the ellipsoid ξ(P, η), the consensus errors evolution for the four agents are drawn in Fig. 2, from which we see that the agents can reach consensus in finite seconds. The evolutions of the adaptive triggering parameters μ i (t) are shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 4 shows the evolution of the control of the four agents, it is obvious that the magnitude of the control is less than u 0 .
Case 2. The sampled-data based event-triggered control.

For this case, u i (t) is defined in (26), the triggering conditions in (5) with triggering functions in (24)(25) are applied to the event-triggered control strategy. By solving the corresponding LMIs (30)(31) in Theorem 2 with L = 0.1, ρ 1 = 0.02, ρ 2 = 0.01, u 0 = 1 and μ i (0) = 0.2, d i = 1, i ∈ S 4 , the sampling period h is chosen as h = 0.02s,we find out the triggering parameter matrices Ω i and the feedback gain matrix K as for the four agents are shown in Fig. 5, obviously, the consensus performance is similar with Case 1. The adaptive triggering parameters μ i (t) are given in Fig. 6. and Fig. 7 shows the evolution of the control of the four agents, it is obvious that the magnitude of the control is also less than u 0 . This demonstrates the effectiveness of our proposed method.

During the same simulation time interval [0, 6s], the released numbers of the four agents for the two cases are shown in Table 1. It is obvious that the released numbers for Case 2 are much less than Case 1, which means that the sampled-data based event-triggered communication scheme has advantages in saving the communication resources compared with the continuous-time based event-triggered communication scheme. This is consistent with our theoretical results.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In order to save the communication resources and reduce the communication burden for the multi-agent network, distributed adaptive event-triggered consensus control is proposed for nonlinear MASs with input saturation in this By using the sector nonlinearity model approach to deal with the input saturation and by using the Lyapunov functional analysis method, sufficient conditions in forms of linear matrix inequalities have been derived to guarantee the consensus in local sense. One simulation example is given at last to show the effectiveness of the proposed adaptive event-triggered control schemes.
